This question is synced with an identical question on Metaculus. The original question opened on 2025-07-26 12:00:00 and can be found [here](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/38938). This question will resolve to the same value as the synced question. The original question's background info at this time is below. 

The [Thai-Cambodian border dispute](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2008%E2%80%932013_Cambodian%E2%80%93Thai_border_crisis#Background) is an ongoing conflict centred around the 11th‑century Khmer temples of [Preah Vihear](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Preah_Vihear_Temple) and [Ta Muen Thom](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prasat_Ta_Muen_Thom). Cambodia has relied on the [1907 French‑produced map](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Franco-Siamese_treaty_of_1907), while Thailand argues it was never formally accepted, leaving roughly 4.6 km² of overlapping claims. The International Court of Justice [awarded sovereignty](https://www.icj-cij.org/case/45) over Preah Vihear to Cambodia in 1962 and clarified in 2013 that the surrounding promontory also falls under Cambodian control, yet adjacent tracts remain contested. [Border skirmishes in 2008–11](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2008%E2%80%932013_Cambodian%E2%80%93Thai_border_crisis) killed fourty individuals and displaced thousands.

Tensions flared again on [28 May 2025](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Cambodia%E2%80%93Thailand_border_conflict) when troops exchanged fire near Preah Vihear, escalating over two months into the deadliest clash between the countries in over a decade, with artillery duels, Thai F‑16 strikes, more than 20 fatalities, the evacuation of more than 130,000 Thai civilians, closure of all crossing points, and an emergency UN Security Council session. On the July 25, Thailand [rejected](https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/thailand-favours-direct-talks-end-cambodia-conflict-rather-than-mediation-2025-07-25/) mediation offers from The United States, China, and Malaysia, saying that they would like to resolve the dispute bilaterally. In response, Cambodian prime minister Hun Manet [revealed](https://www.khmertimeskh.com/501725013/hun-manet-reaffirms-cambodias-support-for-ceasefire-amid-thai-retraction/) that Cambodia and Thailand had initially agreed on a ceasefire proposed by Malaysian prime minister Anwar Ibrahim, but Thailand retracted from it an hour before it came into effect.

This question will resolve as **Yes** if military conflict between Thailand and Cambodia results in at least 500 deaths after May 27, 2025 and before January 1, 2026, according to [credible sources](https://www.metaculus.com/faq/#definitions).

Independent estimates of the number of deaths will be prioritised in resolving this question. These may include cases where an independent organisation has reviewed and explicitly endorsed one side's death figures. If no such estimates are available or if they are judged by Metaculus to be in error, this question will resolve according to each side's count of their own dead.
question_details.fine_print:
* The deaths have to occur in Thai and/or Cambodian territory, as demarcated by their internationally recognised state borders. Deaths in disputed territories between the two countries will be included.
* The deaths have to be caused by the overtly flagged military forces of Thailand, Cambodia, and/or their explicit allies in the conflict.
* The conflict need not involve Thailand forces within the borders of Cambodia or vice-versa, cross-border missile or ballistic attacks are sufficient.
* The deaths must be caused by [kinetic attacks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kinetic_military_action), using weaponry or physical violence. A cyberattack would not count, even one resulting in deaths.
* In case of conflicting information between sources, Metaculus might wait until the end of the tournament to resolve this question or might make a determination as to which sources should contribute to its resolution.

**Video shows Thai-Cambodian border temple argument, not incursion into Bangladesh**
A 14-second video circulating online on October 4, 2025, falsely claimed to show the Arakan Army, an ethnic armed group from Myanmar, entering Bangladesh and attacking Bengali families, following violent protests in Khagrachari district that left three people dead on September 28. The video, however, actually depicts a confrontation between Thai and Cambodian soldiers at a disputed border temple near Prasat Ta Muen Thom (or Prasat Ta Moan Thom) on July 15, 2025—more than two months before the Bangladesh protests. The footage, which has been viewed over 6,000 times, was shared with a Bengali caption referencing the 'Bandarban Border' and the hashtag 'Bandarban Border', misleadingly linking it to Bangladesh. Reverse image searches and cross-referencing with reports from Thai media outlet The Nation and AFP confirm the video’s origin in a territorial dispute between Thailand and Cambodia. The conflict, which began in May 2025, escalated in late July, resulting in at least 43 deaths and over 300,000 displaced. Both nations later agreed to restore normalcy. The soldiers’ uniforms match those in an AFP photo taken on March 26, and the voices in the video are confirmed to be in Khmer, not Burmese or Bengali. No official reports confirm any incursion by an ethnic armed group into Bangladesh.

**Cambodia, Thailand convene JBC meeting to advance vital border discussions**
Cambodia and Thailand convened a two-day meeting of the Joint Border Committee (JBC) in Chanthaburi, Thailand, on October 21, 2025, to advance ongoing border discussions. The meeting, held at noon, focused on reviewing outcomes from the sixth JBC session in Phnom Penh (June 14–15, 2025), following up on priority issues raised during a special General Border Committee (GBC) meeting in Koh Kong on September 10—particularly concerning Chouk Chey village—and other related matters. The agenda includes closed and plenary sessions, with formal approval expected during the plenary meeting. The Cambodian delegation, led by JBC chair Lam Chea, Minister in Charge of the State Secretariat of Border Affairs (SSBA), included representatives from relevant ministries and border provinces. The Thai delegation, headed by Prasas Prasasvinitchai, advisor to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Chairman of the Thailand-Cambodia Land Border Joint Committee, included senior officials. This meeting follows the first JBC session in Phnom Penh in April 2025—the first in over a decade—held amid rising tensions that escalated into armed confrontations between border troops. During the June session, co-chaired by Lam Chea and Prasas Prasasvinitchai, the two sides reviewed 74 boundary pillars, confirmed 45 locations, and adopted LiDAR and orthophoto technologies to accelerate demarcation. Cambodia described the June talks as productive and cooperative, reaffirming that border issues should be resolved through bilateral mechanisms under the 2000 Memorandum of Understanding. Cambodia reiterated its rejection of a unilaterally drawn Thai map, stating it cannot serve as a reference for official survey work. Disputed areas—including Ta Moan Thom, Ta Moan Touch, Ta Krabei, and the Mom Bei (Emerald Triangle) zone—remain outside the JBC’s immediate scope, with Phnom Penh maintaining that these cases should be addressed via the International Court of Justice.

**Cambodia Accuses Thailand of Psychological Warfare Using Ghost Sounds**
Tensions along the Cambodian-Thai border have taken a surreal turn, with Cambodia's Senate Chairman Hun Sen accusing Thailand of using 'ghost sounds' as a tool of psychological warfare. Residents in border areas reported hearing piercing, pre-recorded sounds—such as children crying, dogs barking, chains rattling, and helicopter roars—broadcast from loudspeakers at levels causing physical discomfort. The Cambodian Human Rights Commission has appealed to UN High Commissioner for Human Rights Volker Türk, describing the actions as a 'gross violation of human rights' involving 'disturbing sounds used as a form of psychological intimidation and persecution.' The impact on vulnerable groups, particularly children, has been severe: according to the Executive Director of Cambodia's Child Protection Coalition, Yan Lay, these sounds disrupt children's sleep, trigger nightmares and panic attacks, and hinder their ability to concentrate in school, with long-term consequences for mental health and development. The Commission emphasized that the sonic attacks affect women, children, the elderly, the sick, and disabled, violating their fundamental right to peaceful living. This follows a ceasefire agreement reached in July 2025, brokered by Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim and confirmed after a phone call between U.S. President Donald Trump and the leaders of both countries, ending the deadliest border clashes in over a decade, which killed around 40 people and displaced hundreds of thousands. The conflict began near the ancient Ta Moan Tom temple in Thailand’s Surin province and spread across 817 kilometers of contested border, with Cambodia accusing Thailand of conducting airstrikes inside its territory. The self-proclaimed Thai activist Kannawat Pongpibulvech claimed responsibility, stating he acted with approval from the Thai military to monitor border security and expel Cambodian settlers he alleged had invaded Thai land. However, the use of psychological sound warfare raises serious concerns about compliance with international humanitarian law and the protection of civilians. Hun Sen informed Malaysian Deputy Prime Minister Ahmad Zahid Hamidi of the situation, expressing gratitude for the ceasefire facilitation while voicing concern over ongoing tensions.

**Cambodia, Thailand Continue Talks on Border Peace Agreement**
Cambodia and Thailand are continuing peace talks in Kuala Lumpur ahead of the October 26–28 ASEAN Summit, focusing on mutual troop withdrawals, mine clearance, and the release of 18 Cambodian soldiers detained by Thailand since a ceasefire on July 28 ended five days of intense fighting that killed at least 43 people and displaced over 300,000. Cambodia's Foreign Minister Prak Sokhonn stated that the agreement will include restoring diplomatic relations, combating online scams, demining border areas, and withdrawing weapons from border zones. Thailand has agreed to release the 18 soldiers 'without delay' after the agreement is signed, but insists on four conditions: troop withdrawal from border areas, joint demining, cooperation in eliminating cyber scams targeting Thais, and resettlement of Cambodian citizens alleged to have encroached into Thai territory. Thai military spokesperson Maj. Gen. Withai Laithomya reiterated that the release is contingent on Cambodia fulfilling these demands. Cambodia’s Prime Minister Hun Manet clarified that the agreement will not involve territorial concessions, emphasizing it is about establishing 'conditions and codes of conduct' to restore peace and relations. Despite progress on troop withdrawals and mine clearance, trust remains low, and nationalist sentiment in both countries limits negotiable ground. The U.S. President Donald Trump is expected to attend the ASEAN Summit and preside over the signing of the 'Kuala Lumpur Declaration,' though his attendance remains unconfirmed. The agreement is seen as a necessary first step toward normalizing relations, but unlikely to resolve the underlying border dispute rooted in the 1907 French Indochina–Siam treaty, which would require independent demarcation, territorial compromises, and possible land exchanges.

**Sudan Under Fire: Drone Strikes Kill Civilians, UN Warns of Impending Humanitarian Catastrophe**
The United Nations warned of a worsening humanitarian crisis in Sudan due to escalating violence across multiple regions, emphasizing that civilians are bearing the brunt of the conflict. According to UN spokesperson Stéphane Dujarric, armed clashes intensified in North and West Darfur, with a drone strike on the main market in Seraf Omarah killing at least seven civilians, and similar attacks in al-Jinina, the capital of West Darfur, causing additional casualties. Tensions also rose in West Kordofan, where nearly 1,000 people fled the town of Lqaawa due to deteriorating security, while the cities of Dilling and Kadugli in South Kordofan remain under siege with disrupted supplies and shortages of basic goods. In the Blue Nile state, reports indicate that fighting between armed groups displaced around 600 people from the town of But in the Tamaan locality last week. Dujarric affirmed that humanitarian workers continue to deliver aid in accessible areas despite severe field challenges and called for an 'immediate cessation of hostilities, protection of civilians, and unimpeded access for humanitarian assistance to all affected areas.' The conflict in Sudan began on April 15, 2023, between the Sudanese Armed Forces led by General Abdel Fattah al-Burhan and the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) led by General Mohamed Hamdan Dagalo (Hemedti), resulting in hundreds of deaths, thousands of injuries, widespread internal displacement, and a deepening humanitarian emergency. Despite regional and international mediation efforts, no lasting ceasefire has been achieved, with growing warnings of an imminent humanitarian catastrophe if fighting continues.

Fatalities from violence more than doubled in September despite a drop in overall event frequency. In Papua New Guinea, retaliatory violence between the Yangakuni and Yakuman tribes in Wapenamanda district resumed after a failed truce, triggered by the killing of two Yakuman men following an assassination attempt on MP Miki Kaeok. The violence disrupted education, roads, and courts, prompting the National Court in Wabag to issue interim orders banning hostilities, weapons, and roadblocks, with penalties for contempt. In the Philippines, mass protests on 21 September against government corruption drew at least 100,000 participants in Manila and Quezon City. While most demonstrations were peaceful, the Manila march turned violent when masked youths attacked police, resulting in two deaths and 216 arrests, including 91 minors. A brawl erupted on EDSA between pro-Duterte and anti-Duterte groups, with calls for President Marcos Jr. to resign. The protests followed Senate inquiries into substandard infrastructure projects and were timed to coincide with the 53rd anniversary of martial law under Ferdinand Marcos Sr., marking a fourfold increase in protest activity compared to August.

**Puno Border Conflict Escalates: One Dead, Two Injured, and Communities Isolated Amid Ongoing Dispute**
A violent clash occurred on October 13, 2025, in the Puno region of Peru between residents of Limbani (Sandia) and Coasa (Carabaya) over longstanding border disputes, particularly around the Inambari River. The conflict, which escalated after Limbani residents attacked Coasa residents in the Sahuana sector, led to a deadly confrontation involving police and armed individuals. According to reports, one person was killed and two others were detained (suspected Limbani residents). Two civilians, Demetrio Gómez (wounded in the leg) and Flora Calcina (wounded in the abdomen), were injured and unable to be evacuated due to continuous gunfire. Both victims were reportedly not involved in the conflict but were traveling when attacked. The Inambari River was blockaded by armed individuals, isolating entire communities such as Huanacuri and Jatun Yunca. Residents reported being 'held hostage in their own territory,' with no access to food, medical care, or emergency evacuation. The police attempted to break the blockade, resulting in the death of one person and two arrests. The president of the Coasa Defense Front, Ali Zárate Calsina, accused Belinda Cabada, a regional mediator, of failing to act despite documented requests for mediation in 2024. Coasa issued a one-week ultimatum to restart dialogue, warning of a potential blockade of the Interoceanic Highway if no response is received. Three communities—Huanicachi, Huayruruni, and Jatun Yunka—reported invasions. The Defensoría del Pueblo and the Superintendencia were notified, but responses have been slow. The situation echoes a similar conflict in 2023, when Cabada canceled key meetings, leading to accusations of partiality. The crisis remains unresolved, with calls for immediate government intervention and a dialogue table. Limbani authorities have remained silent.
